item.title: Ethan Gruber on "Oral History Metadata Standards and Schemes"
item.dc:creator: Ethan Gruber
item.description:
The Faulkner audio collection consists of TEI files that are transcriptions of tapes of William Faulkner doing Q&A sessions back in the 1950s -> http://faulkner.lib.virginia.edu/

There are elements in TEI for recording timestamps of "events" in a dialog as well as speakers, and presumably questions.

Check the following for more information:

http://bancroft.berkeley.edu/ROHO/collections/ohonline.html
http://www.diglib.org/standards/level4oh.html
http://www.cdlib.org/groups/stwg/OH_BPG.html

item.title: Erin Bell on "Oral History Metadata Standards and Schemes"
item.dc:creator: Erin Bell
item.description:
Replying to @Ethan Gruber's post:

Ethan, can you tell me more about this? Ideally, I would like to use TEI (or something similar) not only to mark up a transcription and/or a simplified minute-by-minute interview log, I would also like to connect certain moments to points in the audio file. Like something marked <question> would move to that moment. Make sense? Some desktop software does this but as far as I know not according to any standard. If you have some documentation about oral history and TEI, it would be really helpful.

Thanks!

item.title: Erin Bell on "Oral History Metadata Standards and Schemes"
item.dc:creator: Erin Bell
item.description:
I'm wondering if anyone knows of an ideal metadata scheme for digital oral history projects and collections. I've seen many different approaches, most often DublinCore-based, but none seem to follow any identifiable standard specific to the oral history medium or field as a whole. In addition to the use of DublinCore et al, have there been any attempts to create or use something like PBCore (NPR/PBS multimedia metadata scheme http://pbcore.org/2.0/) that answers specifically to some of the unique characteristics of oral history media? Are there any agreed upon standards, exemplary use cases, important articles, etc.?

EDIT: I've created a public open Zotero Group that explores this issue as well. Join/Add if interested: https://www.zotero.org/groups/digital_oral_history_and_metadata
